channel.title: Tags on FooBrr
channel.description: Recent content in Tags on FooBrr

item.title: Privacy From Facebook
item.description:
Facebook is one of the most widely used social media networks out there. Almost everyone who has ever browsed the internet has an account on Facebook. People love sharing their pictures with friends and family on Facebook. People share their opinions and discuss a wide range of topics on Facebook Groups, find roommates, sell stuff etc., on Facebook.

Few know Facebook is not just a social media network. A major portion of their earnings is from their Ad network. Facebook is likely on par with Google in terms of tracking users across the web. Their tracking is not limited to just facebook.com or Instagram. Their sphere of influence extends far and wide beyond that.

Disabling or deleting facebook or instagram profile/account is not the end of story sadly. A robust way to stop these trackers is stopping your computer from trying to connect with the facebook servers. And no, it’s not just facebook.com unfortunately.

A group of privacy minded people maintain a list of domains that can be safely added to a blocklist to prevent tracking from facebook. What this does is the following:

  1. Add a domain name to the hosts file (details explained below)
  2. Tell your computer to connect to nowhere instead of those specific domains.

As an example, should you want to block example.com, then in your hosts file, add this entry:

0.0.0.0 example.com

Here, 0.0.0.0 is the IP address to be connected to example.com is the site

So essentially, what this does is, it tells the computer to route requests for example.com to 0.0.0.0 (nowhere :D)

On the bright side, this should not take more than 10 mins the first time. On the flip side, this is a cat and mouse game - the list gets updated, albeit infrequenty, so you have to update too. But the biggest drawback is that these block lists work at the device level - if you have a windows laptop, a mac and a gaming desktop, then you have to do this on all devices.

Here are the steps that one needs to follow (instructions are for Windows 10):

Open this file in Notepad (or any other editor of your choice):
    C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts
Scroll to the bottom and add the following (copy paste):

Domains for facebook:

0.0.0.0 0-edge-chat.facebook.com
0.0.0.0 1-edge-chat.facebook.com
0.0.0.0 2-edge-chat.facebook.com
0.0.0.0 3-edge-chat.facebook.com
0.0.0.0 4-edge-chat.facebook.com
0.0.0.0 5-edge-chat.facebook.com
0.0.0.0 6-edge-chat.facebook.com

0.0.0.0 z-m.c10r.facebook.com
0.0.0.0 z-m.facebook.com
0.0.0.0 beta.facebook.com
0.0.0.0 pl-pl.facebook.com
0.0.0.0 nl-nl.facebook.com
0.0.0.0 developers.facebook.com

More such lists can be found at source[0]. They include other companies and various combinations.

[0] https://github.com/jmdugan/blocklists/blob/master/corporations/facebook/facebook.com

item.title: Post Two: Running Notes for Mac
item.description:
My second post here (well, first, ignoring the Hello World.

This is more of a collection of notes that I’m trying to maintain of some of the commands that I use(d) on my MacBook Pro.

  • Keep an eye on the Charge levels over the course of the past few days (weeks?)
$ pmset -g log | grep -w Charge
  • Get a count of number of battery cylces.
$ system_profiler SPPowerDataType | grep "Cycle Count" | awk '{print $3}'

Output will be an integer. Example: 432

  • Get the status of battery.
$ system_profiler SPPowerDataType | grep "Condition" | awk '{print $2}'

Output will be a text indicating the status of battery. Example: Normal

  • Get more details about battery:
$ system_profiler SPPowerDataType | grep -A3 -B7 "Condition"

Output will be similar to:

    Charge Information:
      Charge Remaining (mAh): 2405
      Fully Charged: No
      Charging: No
      Full Charge Capacity (mAh): 5321
    Health Information:
      Cycle Count: 123
      Condition: Normal
    Battery Installed: Yes
    Amperage (mA): -24
    Voltage (mV): 11852

item.title: Hello World
item.description:
Introduction

As someone who has a fleeting interest in writing technical and non-technical posts, I have been looking for some lightweight solution to a writing pad. Some years ago, I extensively used Wordpress for my writing, first using the Wordpress platform and then slowly moving on to self hosted Wordpress blog. As work committments increased, maintaining a self hosted blog became a chore.

Over the past few months, I’ve noticed this solution gaining popularity among some people of using Github to host static pages and then using one of the many themes from Jekyll or Hugo to create the static site.

To scratch that itch, here is my page, powered by Hugo.
